title: Before 9 October 2020, will the music festival Coachella, which has been rescheduled for October 2020, be postponed or canceled?
preds: It seems a decision by Riverside Public Health officials has become aired before the organizers could announce it... https://www.npr.org/sections/coronavirus-live-updates/2020/06/10/874508129/coachella-festival-canceled-in-2020-says-public-health-commissioner "The popular annual music festival Coachella and its country music sibling, Stagecoach, have both been canceled for 2020. While the events' promoter, Goldenvoice, has not yet made a public announcement, the cancellation order was released Wednesday evening by the public health officer of Riverside County, Calif."
just read @pstamp forecast and he has point. It's really early to go 90 percent.

Going down a little again after short period of confusion. If it´s cancelled, my accuracy score will get hit superhard anyway for this question. And I simply don´t believe in "certain cancellation". Very probable maybe, but not certain. It was about 50:50 so far, perhaps up to 70:30 now. Reasons: 1) Partial event is still possible: they seem not to have asked all (!) artists about attendance next year. 
2) And asking them could all have been just precautions. Of course they have some kind of risk management, looking for possible alternatives IF things go wrong.
3) Number of COVID cases is going down in spite of the openings in most states and massively increased testing. It´s a clear trend, observable in all countries that have been hit hard. It´s getting better. 
4) Still 4 months till the event is planned to happen. 4 months ago nobody was talking about COVID 19 (only some crazy forecasters like me). In my part of Germany meetings of up to 250 people will be allowed again in a week. Open air, in the desert, with restrictions, in 4 months - at least thinkable. Feels funny to be one of not even a handfull of forecasters being optimistic on this one. 
@nigster : Yes, I  was a coward for a while, but the crowd is too pessimistic here. If it isn´t cancelled in the next 4 weeks, Coachella will happen somehow.
according to bloomberg Goldenvoice have asked artists to perform in 2021 insead of 2020.

Increasing from 35% because lifting lockdown is going slowly but mostly because the crowd is at 96% and I'm thinking I must be missing something. Status of large California music festivals; Aug 01 - (CANCELLED) HARD Summer, Fontana, August 1-2
Aug 07 - (GOING AHEAD) Outside Lands Music and Arts Festival, San Francisco, August 7-9
Sep 18 - (GOING AHEAD) KAABOO San Diego, September 18-20
Oct 02 - (GOING AHEAD) BottleRock 2020, Napa Valley, October 2–4
Oct 09 - (GOING AHEAD) Coachella, Indio, October 9-11 & 16-18
Oct 23 - (GOING AHEAD) Stagecoach, Indio, October 23-25
Nov 07 - (UNCONFIRMED) Camp Flog Gnaw Carnival, Los Angeles, November 7-8 https://www.hardsummer.com/

https://www.kaaboosd.com/
https://www.bottlerocknapavalley.com/
https://www.coachella.com/
https://www.stagecoachfestival.com/

Artists booked for October being asked to play in 2021 instead. https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-05-27/coachella-concert-organizers-ask-acts-to-play-next-year-instead.
Large public gatherings will be the last thing allowed and I have a hard time seeing it happen this year. I'm quite convinced we won't be out of the pandemic come this autumn.
SUPER-SPREADERS not only sounds like a great band name, but also will 100% be the Coachella 2020 main stage headliner if it the festival isn't cancelled...

Reporting from April shows Gov. Newsom and other public health officials indicating that large festivals won't happen at all in 2020. However, we should account for the possibility of a vaccine or antibody treatments making it possible for either a partial cancellation/postponement or no cancellation/postponement.

Increasing pessimism about large events anywhere in balance of 2020.  Move from 65% to 75%.  I think there is still a chance that the combination of reduced infection rates, successful partial reopening and weariness will result in a change to a less distanced way of living.
Masks are common feature which makes the event ironic. Air traffic likely increases by October.
Raising as many big events into the fall are being cancelled.

Getting a little more optimistic for two reasons:
1) Latest numbers from the US
2) A study by Charite Clinics Berlin showed 34% of healthy (!) people having antibodies against coronavirusses in their blood. That could mean having gained immunity from just having had a cold caused by other coronavirusses. 34% is quite a lot...
https://www.focus.de/gesundheit/ratgeber/erkaeltung/kreuz-reaktivitaet-nachgewiesen-immun-dank-ueberstandenem-schnupfen-immunologe-erklaert-worauf-wir-hoffen-duerfen_id_11970024.html

Reducing from 40%. Being in the UK it's tricky to get a sense of what's going on in the US and specifically California. This Channel 4 clip shows Americans getting back to normal in Florida; https://www.channel4.com/news/us-states-ease-lockdown-restrictions But lockdown seems to be becoming politicised in the sense that Dems and Dem state governors appear to want to keep people at home and Reps want to get things back to normal and get people back to work to help Trump in November because "it's the economy, stupid". EDIT; A painfully waffling and rambling article [1] has some interesting numbers buried deep in its belly; "The team tested 624 people who had tested positive for the virus and had recovered. At first, just 511 of them had high antibody levels; 42 had low levels; and 71 had none. When 64 of the subjects with weak or no levels were retested more than a week later, however, all but three had at least some antibodies." That's a small sample size but it implies that after a few weeks the vast majority of people cannot get caronavirus again once they've had it. EDIT 2; China has bounced back; "Air pollution has returned with a vengeance as factories rush to ramp up output after going idle during the outbreak. 'What is interesting is how rapidly the emissions have rebounded after the sharp fall seen in the first three months of the year,' Li Shuo, a climate and energy expert at Greenpeace China, told AFP." [2]. [1] https://www.nytimes.com/2020/05/07/health/coronavirus-antibody-prevalence.html
[2] https://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/asia/china-smog-covid-19-pollution-factories-12715934 Crowd: 95%.

Increasing from 35% because this is becoming an overtly political issue. California Governor Gavin Newsom is thinking ahead to November; https://www.gov.ca.gov/2020/05/08/governor-newsom-issues-executive-order-to-protect-public-health-by-mailing-every-registered-voter-a-ballot-ahead-of-the-november-general-election/ Hilary Clinton likes his announcement; "I hope other governors around the country follow @GavinNewsom’s lead." https://twitter.com/HillaryClinton/status/1258869801860182019 Somebody once said "It's the economy stupid". Dems need to stifle the economy in order to hurt Trump and Reps need to get the economy going again to help him. Crowd: 95%.
Lowering. California guidance would allow some form of it. Still thinking cancellation but lowering as traditionally it has been held no matter what.

Burning Man has been cancelled for 2020 [1], a state rep has raised cancelling it as a possibility [2], and Taylor Swift (among others) are cancelling their tours [3]. If it does go on, I wonder who will be willing to perform? [1] https://www.desertsun.com/story/life/entertainment/music/coachella/2020/04/14/coachella-festival-october-expert-says-were-talking-fall-2021/2983298001/
[2] https://kesq.com/news/coronavirus/2020/04/20/rep-ruiz-there-is-a-possibility-coachella-stagecoach-may-not-happen-in-2020/
[3] https://www.foxbusiness.com/lifestyle/coronavirus-concerns-prompt-taylor-swift-to-cancel-all-2020-live-performances

Increasing from 25% because according to an article [1] in The Week, Italy (which is a few weeks ahead of California in the evolution of coronavirus) has released a very cautious timetable for lifting lockdown; 04 May: Parks, takeaways, construction sites and wholesalers to reopen.
18 May: Museums, libraries and more retailers to reopen.
01 Jun: Bars, restaurants and beauty salons to reopen. Schools will not reopen until September. There is no specific mention in the article of mass-gatherings like music festivals however schools are mass-gatherings. Side note: The Italian government has forecasted [2] that due to caronavirus their debt to GDP ratio will jump from 135% to 156% and the EU has forecasted [2] that it will jump to 159%. To put that in perspective Greece had to be bailed out when it got to about 165%. However Italy is too big to be bailed out. It has 2.4 trillion euros of debt compared to Greece which from memory had about 300 billion. Interesting times ahead. [1] https://www.theweek.co.uk/coronavirus/106805/italy-s-timetable-for-lifting-coronavirus-lockdown
[2] https://www.thelocal.it/20200425/coronavirus-italy-unveils-punishing-public-debt-and-deficit-forecasts
[3] https://uk.investing.com/news/coronavirus/eu-sees-italy-debt-ballooning-to-nearly-160-this-year-amid-coronavirus-crisis-2112657 Crowd: 94%.

Lowering because if this: https://www.nytimes.com/2020/05/04/us/coronavirus-live-updates.html#link-7b42d0f5 happens then there might be some type of herd immunity. And also 68% seems a little overconfident for me.

Will totally rethink all about COVID-19 in the US tomorrow (for now I´m too stunned to do so). Reason: https://www.nytimes.com/2020/05/04/us/coronavirus-live-updates.html#link-7b42d0f5 It would be the worst case on the whole planet. No other country managed it as badly so far. 200 countries with more or less predictable sigmoid functions running. And then there´s the country with the most cases and deaths of all - and their administration expects it to get even much, much worse than it has been so far.

Coachella was postponed by 10th of March, i.e. moved from mid April to mid October.  An event like Coachella will need a month's work to put together - i.e. work should start in September for the event to be held in October.  Seems difficult ATM. 80% chance of being cancelled.
There won't be large gatherings until we have a vaccine.

Down a little again.  1) Kieler Woche (September 2020) will take place, although most probably only the sailing part. 
2) Summerfest Milwaukee (September 2020) is still a go:
https://www.summerfest.com/lineup/
I think I was some what over-confident with 70%. It's to early to go any higher.

Optimism growing, going down a little again.
1) You can still buy tickets
https://www.coachella.com/passes
2) According to LHME (Gates Foundation) most of the outbreak will be over end of june
https://covid19.healthdata.org/united-states-of-america
3) Hamburg´s Reeperbahn Festival  (16-19 September) is still a go, even recruiting new artists
https://www.reeperbahnfestival.com/en/festival/programme

Reducing slightly from 23% because Deborah Birx said on Saturday that hospitalisations, ICU cases and fatalities will all be "dramatically decreased by the end of May". That would leave four months before Coachella is scheduled to happen which I think is plenty of time for all the restrictions to be lifted whilst still leaving enough time for event planning; https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=yA1hBTpXvb4&t=21s EDIT 2020-04-30; California's coronavirus death rate is 0.005% (~2,000 fatalities from a population of ~40,000,000). For perspective ~3,500 people die each year due to traffic accidents. 
According to Statista, California currently has 5 coronavirus deaths per 100,000 population compared to New York's 120 deaths per 100,000; • https://www.statista.com/statistics/1109011/coronavirus-covid19-death-rates-us-by-state/ Crowd: 90%.

I believe it is likely that there will be a significant outbreak of COVID-19 in the fall (https://www.gjopen.com/questions/1596-for-any-seven-consecutive-day-period-between-1-october-and-31-december-2020-will-there-be-200-000-or-more-combined-total-confirmed-new-cases-of-covid-19-in-the-united-states), so I believe this is likely as well.
Feels like you need either a vaccine or a cure to make this happen. Especially given the planning will need to be progressing very soon for it to be possible.

Reducing slightly from 25% because the mood in the UK is changing from cautious to bullish. Small shops and businesses are starting to reopen even tho the formal government guidelines haven't changed. The public are getting lockdown fatigue. Headlines within the last 24 hours; "Greggs to begin reopening shops amid lockdown"
"Redrow joins peers and becomes next housebuilder to reopen sites"
"Burger King is to open 10 more restaurants, allowing customers around the country to order items on a takeaway basis"
"Tories call for garden centres to be allowed to reopen – Good for ‘mental health’"
"John Lewis gets ready to reopen all 50 stores in by mid May in new plan" Businesses are straining at the leash to get up and running again; https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-52431295 Crowd: 90%.

Near zero chance of large scale, close proximity events like major sports or music festivals occurring prior to a vaccine, without major, unexpected breakthroughs in treatment and testing at large scale.

The festival occurs in CA, which has proven to be one of the strictest states for enforcing lockdown. There are numerous unknowns about COVID-19 and there will likely be little further clarity by October. Therefore, there is a 75% that Coachella will be canceled.

Californians flocked to the beaches this weekend despite the lockdown/stay-at-home order.  Coachella in October will be swamped. The state officials will be anxious about that in view of the uncertainty about the second wave of outbreaks.  Oktoberfest in Munich just cancelled.  Unless some developments revealing more on the coronavirus or Covid-19 in the summer, it is likely that Coachilla will be cancelled.

Due to a travel ban and no projected date of uplift, they could potentially lose 20% of sales. In conclusion I believe it will be postponed to 2021 and ticket owners will still hold their tickets till next year with an optional refund rather than canceling the entire event.
https://www.scientificamerican.com/article/when-can-we-lift-the-coronavirus-pandemic-restrictions-not-before-taking-these-steps/ I might raise my forecast % within the next couple of days.
I find this article [1] interesting, not that it changed much of my forecast. [1] https://quillette.com/2020/04/23/covid-19-superspreader-events-in-28-countries-critical-patterns-and-lessons/

Octoberfest was cancelled but there is also a report that the outbreak could have occured earlier than thought in california. That would mean that there is a greater herd immunity than expected. I'm raising because i don't think that there will be that much of a immunity with these thight restrictions.
Watching for cancellations of events closer to October...Oktoberfest (9/19-10/4)
Increasing from 15% due to Oktoberfest being cancelled. h/t @pstamp. Crowd: 90%.

It will be canceled. The US,  will have a high risk of a “second wave” unless drastic social distancing is maintained.
Opening up society requires knowing the risks...without testing,  people exposed remains unknown, immunity unknown.
Large gatherings will be off the books for the foreseeable future, likely until a vaccine is produced (if ever) Population immunity appears insufficient to avoid a second wave if all control measures are released at the end of the lockdown
The US is 'a long way' from beating the coronavirus with herd immunity (*if that is achievable)
Stopping SARS-CoV-2 will require at least 70% of the population to be immune. *Immunity itself is still uncertain! - a huge unknown remains: Who has become immune to the disease — and for how long? * Researchers from Fudan University in China found that nearly a third of the patients they tested had such low levels of coronavirus antibodies, they were unlikely to have any meaningful immunity. The team also found that antibody levels rose with age, with people in the 60-85 age group displaying more than three times the amount of antibodies as people in the 15-39 age group.
The low amounts of antibodies could affect herd immunity, resistance to the disease among the general population to stop its spread.
https://www.scmp.com/news/china/science/article/3078840/coronavirus-low-antibody-levels-raise-questions-about *testing kits and supplies in shortage, slowing the ability to test.
https://www.jhsph.edu/covid-19/articles/achieving-herd-immunity-with-covid19.html
Very very likely, boarding certainty, with the possibility of bad decision making and general unrest opening up outdoor crowd events.

Oktoberfest in Munich (19 Sep to 4 Oct) just got cancelled. Bad news.
On the other hand, it would have been a few weeks earlier than Coachella, mainly indoor (people sitting very close to each other in tents) and taking place in Bavaria (with MP Söder being the one promoting the strictest corona rules in Germany). And Kieler Woche (5-13 Sep; open air, also with live music at huge stages and more moderate MP Günther) so far seems to take place. Staying with 50:50.
Still large crowds pre mass vaccination
It will be fully cancelled, maybe with a partial online replacement.

holding steady as I was way overconfident the other way too long. will slide back to the middle in a few days once I've counteracted the first bad swing.. truthfully i thinks is closer to 50/50 right now... Here's a "what if?"  If it happens, it will be a Close Contact Crowd event, regardless of an online way to watch (which is immaterial, see new APR 14 note in yellow, above)  Would people returning to "everywhere!" from a CCC like Coachella be OBLIGATED to self quarantine/isolate themselves afterwards? Morally, YES, but it would be State laws that mandated it. BUT there will also be some HUGE pent-up demand for a social release like Coachella, etc.. represents..  the forces are gathering on both sides. logic and passion. Type 1 and Type 2 thinking. who will win! This f'rinstance is one of myriad mysteries which add to the complexity of organizers and governments to juggle. Just sayin...  :-)

Germany just forbid all larger conventions till 31 August. Sounds like bad news at first, but I don´t think so. Coachella is scheduled much later, and so far the german Government proved good judgment. If nothing really bad happens, they won´t extend it. IHME sees Germany and the US on the same spot in the curve. Accordingly back to optimistic mode. https://covid19.healthdata.org/united-states-of-america
https://covid19.healthdata.org/germany
https://www.bz-berlin.de/deutschland/grossveranstaltungen-werden-wegen-corona-bis-zum-31-august-verboten

Burning man will build a "virtual Black Rock City", online-only. 
https://journal.burningman.org/2020/04/news/official-announcements/brc-2020-update/
It should have ended a month before Coachella is supposed to start. The US Government seems to believe, that the epidemic will end much earlier (as far as I know, they rely on the following):
https://covid19.healthdata.org/united-states-of-america
Although that might be wishful thinking and economically motivated, and I don´t believe that it will completely be over by the end of june, it will be "almost over" in a few months. Data from many countries suggests, that the kind of curve shown there is quite realistic.
Situation will stabilize and larger meetings will be allowed after summer break
Holding lower on the assumption that if held online it would still count as being held. Burning man has already announced it's going online so it seems likely most fests will go that route.

Festivals take months to prepare appropriate infrastructure, staging, etc. It is in best interests to cancel early if there is any indication that the festival may not be allowed to go ahead to minimise potential losses. Though the initial outbreak is likely to have run its course by this point, the potential for further waves of infection in the absence of a generally available vaccine (the likelihood of which being available at this point is negligible) means that large-scale gatherings like this are very unlikely to go ahead. There could be potential for it to go ahead on the proposed date in an alternative format (online festival?) but not sure how this might work / if this may satisfy the conditions of the question.
Burning Man has been canceled (11 April). The pressure will be on Coachella's organizers to cancel before the losses mount.
usa shutdown will be shorter than those in many other countries. economic considerations will drive the end of the lockdown
Raising a bit due to chances of secondary surge of coronavirus. Especially if economy opened up too soon which seems likely now.

CLARIFICATION RECEIVED:  So I'm now betting that the statement below: "The actual event would have to take place as planned" is far less likely than when I allowed for the "Coachella-like" permutations (several of us had been positing), which would help a NO. So now will look afresh at the developing news on Coachella...   @sebawi @cafebedoiun @pstamp , et al  RECEIVED THIS CLARIFICATION (excerpt): Ultimately, any online activities branded as Coachella or otherwise would be immaterial. The actual event would have to take place as planned for the question to close "No." From: GJ Open Clarifications <clarifications@goodjudgment.com> 
Sent: Thursday, April 09, 2020 11:57 AM
To: Paul Bouchard <paul@bpwood.com>
Subject: Re: Question Clarification: Coachella question. SEMANTICS. Hi Paul,

Yes, we messed up! Sorry about that! Turned a double negative into a triple... Ultimately, any online activities branded as Coachella or otherwise would be immaterial. The actual event would have to take place as planned for the question to close "No." Please let me know if that's more useful.

Best,
Heron Paul Bouchard on April 9, 2020 at 12:55pm wrote:
HI GJP. 
If you read the threads ONLINE FOR THIS QUESTION, and reference the “clarification” sought by @sebawi he posed your previous answer to, (and commented on by @pstamp and by @cafebedouin ) you can see some clarification would be beneficial. 
Can this email serve as a “clarification request”? Pls advice. And THX!

I believe that we will have an emerging second wave of covid 19 sometime in october or november. a lot is still uncertain but i'm guessing that  Gavin Newsom will try to be somewhat early on implementing restrictions the next time so I don't think that a concert like coachella will be allowed. There will be more hesitation to go as hard fighting the outbreak with something like a stay at home-order. I am on the other hand doubtful because of the revenue that coachella brings. i might be over studying this.

this is now a super-hedge. I have been betting heavily (15%-ish) that "some form" of Coachella WILL occur by that date.  Waiting for @sebawi who is trying to clarify the opaque-ifying (i think i invented a word!) "No,No, Not, but Yes..."  clarification the admins provided him earlier this week. Question for knowledgeable readers: Are "clarifications" posted by the admins for all to see?, or only to the forecaster that asked them the question? And where might i research them? Cheers.
Hedging up while this crazy question and the crazier "clarification" provided, gets further clarified. @sebawi is working on it in the meantime. (Thx sebawi)

General lack of artists and potential customers doen´t seem to be an issue here, otherwise it would not have postponed to a clear date in October. So it´s probably mainly about permission by authorities and/or if it´s financially worth the trouble.
a) They get permission, even a limited one (wearing masks, limited number of people etc.) - everything is fine.
b) Bad case if some type of festival is happening at all: scenario with a partial event only online, because they´re not allowed to perform with an audience: I´m wondering if a pure online streaming would raise enough advertising money to get it going even without an audience in place paying for tickets. Or if enough people would pay for watching. on Youtube. After many months without public events (if that was the case by then (I don´t hope and think so), I think they would.
c) Very worst case: full cancellation (which this question is asking for). Question to the crowd concerning point (b): would it financially be enough to do only online, what they did successfully last year (82m views on their live channel)?
https://musically.com/2019/05/03/youtube-coachella-festival-livestream-generated-82m-views/
No vaccine would be available for the public before the end of the year

It seems people are submitting higher probabilities based on today's conditions with the virus -- but that will not be the case in October. The impact of the virus is an exponential curve upward and then a dramatic decline, like a storm that passes through. Yes, we will have outbreaks again in the fall, and yes it's possible that it's cancelled or postponed. But October will not be the same conditions as April 2020.
@pstamp view is making me bolder. I'm back to where I was in my initial bet of mar 20

To me any type of festival under the official name Coachella taking place on any of the mentioned days in October would have to count as "no", because it would happen as a "partial" event. I consider that quite clear. And there will most likely be something like that happening. It could be shown on the screens of Clubs all over the world or on YouTube or however. By the way: a first (although very small) online music festival has already happened here in Germany. And I´ve participated in business training online a week ago. There were five times more participants to it than usually travelled to the original event in Munich. 
And there´s a chance for a live event too. Life will be better then.
Give Coachella a chance. I will attend online, if they offer it there :-)
Risking all the scores of the past: going down to 10% on this one just for the fun of it.

It doesn't seem likely that Covid is ending anytime soon. A vaccine is not going to out anytime soon. The rate of infection is not fast enough for herd immunity to stop it anytime soon. It's possible things get better, but better is not enough to save Coachella. The disease needs to be gone or nearly gone. The only way I can see it not getting postponed or canceled is if the disease mutates and becomes less deadly that seems unlikely. It's also possible we just take the L and give up completely on trying to stop it, but I also don't see that as very likely. The projections do show the number of cases going down to near zero numbers, but that is under the assumption of indefinite shelter-in-place. The second shelter-in-place ends, it's expected the numbers will go up again.

trending towards @pstamp 's view.  With date that far away (6+ Months) , and the possibility that an "online" Coachella would count* it's either ON or OFF on Oct  9. OFF is a Yes. 
*"Online" would resolve as NO, i suspect as do some others I've read... (am i reading that right?) But tricky wording to the question and explanations. Whatever a partial cancellation or partial postponement could be (ideas?) , they wouldn't count towards a YES.
Projected curves for coronavirus, both flattened and otherwise, show that the US will be long past the peak by then.
I'm not sure. It seems like partial postponement or online are options.
I think we'll be through the worst of the coronavirus by then.  Plus, most if not all of the performances are outdoors, lessening the chance of spreading the virus compared to indoor functions.

The coronavirus will have played out by September. Most of those who would have been hospitalized by a COVID-19 infection, have already been hospitalized. There will also be some solution that helps you identify if you are susceptible to the virus or not.

According to current sources - it will be May before the numbers start reducing. No vaccine will put crowds at risk. No fun in standing out with masks in close quarters with high frenzy, not to mention precarious crowds. It will move or cancel. Maybe go online?? But there will be economic impact too, trying to do that

Peak seems lower than expected in European countries after measures. 
Number of infections is hugely underestimated. Herd immunity will play a role soon. 
Fast, cheap, accurate testing will negate most of the fears and contribute to public calm about the disease spread.

We will still not have a vaccine. The number of deaths the United States experiences will be so great that people will readily accept a canceled Coachella. Perhaps there will be a "virtual Coachella". The virus would easily rebound around the whole country if Coachella happens, so it will be canceled.
I change my forecast due to the chance of an online concert that has minimal to no audience. I do not think that it's probible but still there is a slim chance of something like this happening.

The difficulty here is the lack of concrete testing data. As of 25 March (when I am writing this), CDC testing is actually declining for the month, although currently there is incomplete data for any accurate statements. The question is whether the impact of social distancing will itself be enough to slow down the rate of infection. The determining factor for answering the question concerning rescheduling Coachella is whether or not populations maintain social distancing or begin to disregard this (rather ad hoc) policy. If the rate of infection is slowed within the next few weeks, then it is conceivable that people will decide to go on with their lives. If the risks to public health are brought under control in the same time period, and economic life returns, then the social stigma of gathering in groups will subside - thus eliminating another reason for the Coachella festival to be canceled or postponed.  There is a dissenting voice (Michael Levitt, see below) who claims that the outbreak will subside sooner rather than later. It's hard to lend this claim too much credibility, even though his predictions for China were astonishingly accurate. Nevertheless, China and the US have very different dynamics. It is much more difficult to coerce US public behavior. This is especially the case when there appears to be little political appetite for issuing nationwide "shelter in place" orders (as of 25 March). It does not seem to me that Levitt's model for China is applicable to the US.  The problem with the optimistic forecasts is the behavior of Americans themselves. All decisions made at the individual level have nonlinear consequences: asymptomatic people could still be spreading the virus for weeks, infecting thousands of Americans. If communities lose vigilance in maintaining social distancing, then another flare up is easily conceivable - in which case a rescheduling of Coachella would almost be a given.  Also, the pressure to revive the economy is already affecting decision-making at the highest levels. The organizers and owners of Coachella have strong incentives to refrain from cancelling this event or postponing it again.  Sources:  https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/cases-updates/testing-in-us.html https://www.kiro7.com/news/trending/coronavirus-nobel-laureate-says-us-will-have-quicker-covid-19-recovery/AWJN4WAM6VC7NPTBZLDC3JWGUU/ https://www.washingtonpost.com/health/2020/03/19/coronavirus-projections-us/ https://www.wsj.com/articles/how-many-people-might-one-person-with-coronavirus-infect-11581676200 https://www.nature.com/articles/d41586-020-00822-x https://www.newscientist.com/article/2238473-you-could-be-spreading-the-coronavirus-without-realising-youve-got-it/ https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2646474/ https://www.weforum.org/agenda/2020/03/people-with-mild-or-no-symptoms-could-be-spreading-covid-19/

Cancelling the olympics was a close call, and there were many worse aspects to that (participants and viewers from all over the world (this is just US), no way to train and qualify accordingly for the athletes etc. (for Coachella they just need enough artists and customers in October)). Reasons for cancellation:
- Unlikey to have vaccine by October
- Mass events will need to be prohibited to avoid super infectors as e.g. in South Korea even after a potential lock-down has been lifted
- Assuming US enters lock-down in next few weeks across the whole country the lock-down should be over in May; even if spreading of virus is under control by then measures of social distancing will likely still be necessary for the coming months to avoid re-entering the exponential growth phase
- Other countries are forecasting that soccer games will only restart with full stadiums next year for this reason Reasons for no cancellation:
- Some form of vaccine/treatment has been found (unlikely)
- Virus is contained by then through herd immunity (unlikely)
- Decision to allow the festival due to new case numbers fluctuating at low level (R<1, assuming successfull previous lock-down as e.g. in South Korea/China), essentially taking the tail risk of starting new mass breakout

We can say with near certainty that COVID-19 will not be eradicated by October 2020. It is unlikely that a vaccine will be out by then, but there are still things that can hinder COVID-19. It's possible that the pandemic loses steam as more people get infected, and the disease starts to spread less quickly. It is also possible that the disease mutates, and becomes less deadly. In addition, more effective treatments and better testing could also make the disease less deadly. Also, I think the media has overestimated the mortality rate of COVID-19. Looking at South Korea, they have been very effective at testing people for COVID-19, and they see a fatality rate of less than 1%. I think poor testing has caused countries to fail to properly count the less serious cases, hence they overestimated the mortality rate. As the media gets a more accurate account of the mortality rate, people will be less likely to take drastic measures like cancelling Coachella. Despite these facts, COVID-19 is still a serious threat, and it will almost certainly be around in October 2020, so I think it is still more likely than not that Coachella gets cancelled; however, there is a lot of room for change in the next six months.
